_prev_prog_3.Description:
Rich Product Corporation - Hilliard Facility's ammonia refrigeration system is designed to minimize the potential of an ammonia release. The facility has in place the following for the ammonia refrigeration system: preventative maintenance procedures and records, automatic alarm systems, ammonia detectors and ventilation system, process safety information tracking logs, automatic system shutdown capabilities, periodic leak and pressure testing, periodic visual inspections, control valves, refrigeration hand service valves for manual operation, solenoid valves, pressure relief valves, computer generated work orders for maintenance, and hot work permits.



The facility's administrative procedures are as follows: periodic training for associates, compliance audits, pre-startup safety checks, process hazard analysis to address what-if scenarios and the measures taken to mitigate a release, screening of all contractors performing work on the ammonia refrigeration system per OSHA and USEPA regulations, and management of change procedures.



Compressors have the following safeguards: pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping, high and low temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, high and low level oil alarms and shutdown, high and low oil temperature alarms and shutdown, high and low oil pressure alarms and shutdown, thermosyphon oil cooling, discharge stop/check valve, suction valve (i.e., combination stop/check/strainer valve), electronic overload protection with alarm and shutdown conditions, and pressure relief valves.



The intercooler has the following safeguards: dual pressure relief valves, high and low level alarms and shutdown, continuous level controller, and liquid level sight glass. Evaporative Condenser has the following safeguards: dual pressure relief valves, liquid level indicator, water pump startup and shutdown, and high pressure over-ride. High pressure receiver has the following safeguards: dual pressure relief valves, level column with level indicator and level sight glass, and high and low level alarms and shutdown.



Evaporators have the following safeguards: high and low level alarms and shutdown, temperature controls, liquid level alarm and shutdown, liquid level gauge, pressure relief valves, high and low pressure alarms and shutdown, emergency stop switch, and pressure and temperature gauges on suction and discharge piping. Plate and Frame Chiller: high and low level alarms and shutdown, temperature controls, liquid level gauge, and high and low pressure alarms and shutdown.



The Facility has installed an emergency UPS power supply and a diesel-fired emergency electric generator. These allow the refrigeration control system to remain powered during a power failure, which allows the entire ammonia detection system and the emergency ventilation systems to continue to function.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Site has developed this program in accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (CAPP) of the Clean Air Act, as amended (CAAA), a.k.a., the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule, which is codified at 40 CFR 68; the United States Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (HHCs) standard (PSM standard), which is codified at 29 CFR 1910.119; and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency's (OEPA's) Accidental Releases Prevention Program rules, which are codified at Chapter 3745-104 of the Ohio Administrative Code (OAC)(OAC 3745-104). The program is designed to inform all Site employees (hereafter referred to as Associates) of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates in the event of a release or spill (i.e., emergency response plan, management of change procedures, preventative maintenance program, associate training, etc.).



The Site has taken a more conservative approach in calculating the worst case scenario (see below), which is documented in this submission.



RPC is guided by a set of core values that include:



-- Cherish Our Culture - Work, learn and celebrate together;

-- Innovate - Imagine what's possible and create what's valued;

-- Be the Trusted First Choice - Listen, understand and deliver for customers like no other company;

-- Better Our Communities - Devote time and talent where we work and live; and

-- Do What's Right - No matter what.



RPC is committed to an irrevocable obligation to act responsibly in every decision made and with every person encountered. RPC understands it is a trusted steward of its business relationships, its environment and the communities in which it serves. RPC holds itself to the highest set of standards and is about doing what's right...no matter what.





FACILITY DESCRIPTION



Rich Products Corporati

on's (RPC's) Hilliard facility ("Site") is located at 4600 Northwest Parkway in the City of Hilliard, Franklin County, Ohio and is situated in a commercial/light industrial area. The Site occupies an approximately 132,000 square-foot structure that is located on 11.3 acres of land. The Site was originally built in 1980 and has been owned by RPC since 1985. The Site normally operates 6 days per week, 24 hours per day.



The Site manufactures doughnuts, which are frozen for shipment. The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 31141 (Frozen Food Manufacturing)



As part of the refrigeration system to freeze the doughnuts for shipment, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical, as defined in the USEPA's CAPP and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Site is registered to Program Level 3 under the CAPP program.



The anhydrous ammonia is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The Site's engine room houses the majority of the refrigeration machinery.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



In calculating the worst case release scenario, Site personnel have conservatively utilized 100 percent of the largest vessel as the amount released. However, under no circumstances is this analysis intended to indicate that Site personnel fill any vessel to this extent.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION



While there are few long-term environmental consequences to ammonia use, it can present health hazards if handled improperly. RPC has developed a comprehensive safety program in compliance with OSHA and EPA requirements to ensure the responsible management of the ammonia onsite (the Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program, respectively). All refrigeration Associates receive operator training, safe work

practices training and training on the standard operating procedures (SOPs). Safety meetings are conducted to further protect Associates and the community as a whole.



The Site's prevention program is designed to inform all Associates of the hazards of ammonia, procedures for the safe use of ammonia, and the steps taken for the safety of Associates and the community in the event of a release or spill.



The Site endeavors to eliminate accidents and health hazards to Associates, customers, and the community by having procedures in place to provide Associates educational training, safe working conditions, and the means to increase awareness of potential dangers both on and off the job. RPC's objective is to prevent unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could potentially expose Associates and others to serious hazards. An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire system. Workplace and process safety are major concerns to management and Associates alike. The prevention and mitigation of unwanted releases of ammonia into locations that could expose Associates and the community to serious hazards is of primary concern.



The Site has incorporated many safety features in the design of the ammonia refrigeration system to prevent system failures and to mitigate potential releases. The predominant safety concern with closed-loop ammonia systems is an inadvertent buildup of pressure exceeding pressure ratings or capacities of equipment due to ammonia expansion. The Site's ammonia system is continuously monitored by automated control systems that shutdown pump and the components if deviations from normal operating conditions occur. Further, the system is equipped with pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels and most, if not all, additional locations within the ammonia system where ammonia could become trapped.



RPC considers the health and safety of each Associate as its most important responsibility. It is our policy to

provide a healthy and safe work environment. This facility follows operating practices that safeguard all associates and result in safe working conditions while maintaining efficient operations.



Safety is the responsibility of all Associates. Each associate is expected to comply with the requirements of RPC's Standards for Safety Performance. Management is responsible for the implementation, communication, documentation, and necessary training. The Associate is responsible for implementation, communication, and practices of the program. Management is committed to maintain a high level of interest in health and safety throughout this facility. This commitment extends to the associates and their involvement in preventing accidents.



RPC has established its Health and Safety Program to insure that:



-- Associates work in a healthy and safe environment.

-- Associates are trained on safe work practices.

-- Associates practice safe work habits.

-- Management and associates are both involved in the program.

-- There is constant communication between all Associates on safety issues.

-- Compliance with all regulatory agencies is maintained.



Major safety features at the Site include:



-- Installation of Ammonia leak detectors in processing areas and the engine room

-- Remote emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration system

-- Fire sprinklers throughout the Site

-- Component specific safety shutdowns of the refrigeration system

-- Water-filled diffusion tank to treat accidental release of ammonia through pressure relief valves, and

-- A proprietary Refrigeration Energy Management System (REMS) computer monitoring system.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Site has reported one accidental release over the last five years. While a release was reported as having been discovered on October 18, 2014, further additional investigations determined that a reportable release had not occurred.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Site is equipped with

an emergency warning system. Alarms are placed throughout the Site to alarm personnel of an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia or other emergencies that may be encountered. RPC has developed specific procedures to be followed in the event of release. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so. RPC maintains a written emergency response plan; however, Site Associates do not currently respond to releases.



As applicable to their duties, Site personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) and other various rules and regulations.



The Norwich Township Fire Department has visited the facility to review the process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency response coordination.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Site recognizes that the implementation of this program is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operation at the Site. As such, the prevention program will evolve as RPC continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for the employees and the surrounding community.
